title-group.article-title: Motifs in Epistolary Fiction: Analysis of a Narrative Sub-genre

p.mixed-citation: There are only a few studies of the formal and generic possibilities of epistolary fiction. Amongst the best are François Jost, "Le roman épistolaire et la technique narrative au XVIIIe siècle," Comparative Liter- ature Studies, 3 (1966), 397-427, and "L'Evolution d'un genre : le roman épistolaire dans les lettres occidentales," in his Essais de littérature comparée, 2 (Europaena), 89-179, 380-402; Jean Rousset, "Le roman par lettres," in his Forme et signification. Essais sur les structures lit- téraires de Corneille à Claudel (Paris, 1964), pp. 65-108, and "La monodie épistolaire : Crébillon fils" in his Narcisse romancier: Essai sur la première personne dans le roman (Paris, 1973), pp. 114-26. There are several pas- sages in this latter study that treat different aspects of first-person nar- rative in general, and which are helpful to the critic of letter-fiction. See also Jean-Luc Seylaz, Les "Liaisons dangereuses" et la création roma- nesque chez Laclos (Geneva, 1958), Pierre Testud, "Les Lettres persanes, roman épistolaire," RHLF, 66 (1966), 642-56, T. Todorov, Littérature et signification (Paris, 1967). Finally, there is an excellent Ph. D. disserta- tion which hopefully will be soon published, by Janet Altman, entitled "Epistolarity : Approaches to a Form," Diss. Yale University, 1973.

I again send the reader to the unpublished dissertation of Janet Altman, which attempts "to isolate those literary phenomena which are particular to or present in unique ways in the letter form" (p. 7). I would hope that my own study, biased as it is toward a fuller understanding of the development of narrative fiction in general, would complement Profes- sor Altman's. My own approach seeks less to discover what is unique about epistolary fiction than to isolate and understand its narrative con- formity. Nonetheless, our analyses intersect in important ways.

I take the term, though not the meaning, from F. Jost's essay on epistolary fiction in his Essais de littérature comparée, II, 380. The use of this term as one of my motifs bothers me somewhat. It implies that the motif it describes is limited to letter-fiction, an implication that would be anti- thetical to the premise of this essay. It is also a term that has been used by other critics, namely Jost and Altman, for other purposes. Yet the vocabulary of literary criticism provides me with no alternative: "lit- erarity," "textuality," and "literary self-consciousness" are already too specific or too general for my purposes. I trust the reader will allow this slight terminological inconsistency as I try to make clear how the concept extends beyond epistolary fiction.
